column2: I. A DISCUSSION SOMEWHAT IN THE AIR
column3: I. A DISCUSSION SOMEWHAT IN THE AIR

column2: The flying ship of Professor Lucifer sang through the skies like a silver arrow; the bleak white steel of it, gleaming in the bleak blue emptiness of the evening.
column3: The flying ship of Professor Lucifer sang through the skies like a silver arrow; the bleak white steel of it, gleaming in the bleak blue emptiness of the evening.

column2: That it was far above the earth was no expression for it; to the two men in it, it seemed to be far above the stars.
column3: That it was far above the earth was no expression for it; to the two men in it, it seemed to be far above the stars.

column2: The professor had himself invented the flying machine, and had also invented nearly everything in it.
column3: The professor had himself invented the flying machine, and had also invented nearly everything in it.

column2: Every sort of tool or apparatus had, in consequence, to the full, that fantastic and distorted look which belongs to the miracles of science.
column3: Every sort of tool or apparatus had, in consequence, to the full, that fantastic and distorted look which belongs to the miracles of science.

column2: For the world of science and evolution is far more nameless and elusive and like a dream than the world of poetry and religion; since in the latter images and ideas remain themselves eternally, while it is the whole idea of evolution that identities melt into each other as they do in a nightmare.
column3: For the world of science and evolution is far more nameless and elusive and like a dream than the world of poetry and religion; since in the latter images and ideas remain themselves eternally, while it is the whole idea of evolution that identities melt into each other as they do in a nightmare.

column2: All the tools of Professor Lucifer were the ancient human tools gone mad, grown into unrecognizable shapes, forgetful of their origin, forgetful of their names.
column3: All the tools of Professor Lucifer were the ancient human tools gone mad, grown into unrecognizable shapes, forgetful of their origin, forgetful of their names.

column2: That thing which looked like an enormous key with three wheels was really a patent and very deadly revolver.
column3: That thing which looked like an enormous key with three wheels was really a patent and very deadly revolver.

column2: That object which seemed to be created by the entanglement of two corkscrews was really the key.
column3: That object which seemed to be created by the entanglement of two corkscrews was really the key.

column2: The thing which might have been mistaken for a tricycle turned upside-down was the inexpressibly important instrument to which the corkscrew was the key.
column3: The thing which might have been mistaken for a tricycle turned upside-down was the inexpressibly important instrument to which the corkscrew was the key.

column2: All these things, as I say, the professor had invented; he had invented everything in the flying ship, with the exception, perhaps, of himself.
column3: All these things, as I say, the professor had invented; he had invented everything in the flying ship, with the exception, perhaps, of himself.

column2: This he had been born too late actually to inaugurate, but he believed at least, that he had considerably improved it.
column3: This he had been born too late actually to inaugurate, but he believed at least, that he had considerably improved it.

column2: There was, however, another man on board, so to speak, at the time.
column3: There was, however, another man on board, so to speak, at the time.

column2: Him, also, by a curious coincidence, the professor had not invented, and him he had not even very greatly improved, though he had fished him up with a lasso out of his own back garden, in Western Bulgaria, with the pure object of improving him.
column3: Him, also, by a curious coincidence, the professor had not invented, and him he had not even very greatly improved, though he had fished him up with a lasso out of his own back garden, in Western Bulgaria, with the pure object of improving him.

column2: He was an exceedingly holy man, almost entirely covered with white hair.
column3: He was an exceedingly holy man, almost entirely covered with white hair.

column2: You could see nothing but his eyes, and he seemed to talk with them.
column3: You could see nothing but his eyes, and he seemed to talk with them.

column2: A monk of immense learning and acute intellect he had made himself happy in a little stone hut and a little stony garden in the Balkans, chiefly by writing the most crushing refutations of exposures of certain heresies, the last professors of which had been burnt (generally by each other) precisely 1,119 years previously.
column3: A monk of immense learning and acute intellect he had made himself happy in a little stone hut and a little stony garden in the Balkans, chiefly by writing the most crushing refutations of exposures of certain heresies, the last professors of which had been burnt (generally by each other) precisely one thousand one hundred nineteen years previously.

column2: They were really very plausible and thoughtful heresies, and it was really a creditable or even glorious circumstance, that the old monk had been intellectual enough to detect their fallacy; the only misfortune was that nobody in the modern world was intellectual enough even to understand their argument.
column3: They were really very plausible and thoughtful heresies, and it was really a creditable or even glorious circumstance, that the old monk had been intellectual enough to detect their fallacy; the only misfortune was that nobody in the modern world was intellectual enough even to understand their argument.

column2: The old monk, one of whose names was Michael, and the other a name quite impossible to remember or repeat in our Western civilization, had, however, as I have said, made himself quite happy while he was in a mountain hermitage in the society of wild animals.
column3: The old monk, one of whose names was Michael, and the other a name quite impossible to remember or repeat in our Western civilization, had, however, as I have said, made himself quite happy while he was in a mountain hermitage in the society of wild animals.

column2: And now that his luck had lifted him above all the mountains in the society of a wild physicist, he made himself happy still.
column3: And now that his luck had lifted him above all the mountains in the society of a wild physicist, he made himself happy still.

column2: I have no intention, my good Michael, said Professor Lucifer, "of endeavouring to convert you by argument.
column3: I have no intention, my good Michael, said Professor Lucifer, "of endeavouring to convert you by argument.

column2: The imbecility of your traditions can be quite finally exhibited to anybody with mere ordinary knowledge of the world, the same kind of knowledge which teaches us not to sit in draughts or not to encourage friendliness in impecunious people.
column3: The imbecility of your traditions can be quite finally exhibited to anybody with mere ordinary knowledge of the world, the same kind of knowledge which teaches us not to sit in draughts or not to encourage friendliness in impecunious people.

column2: It is folly to talk of this or that demonstrating the rationalist philosophy.
column3: It is folly to talk of this or that demonstrating the rationalist philosophy.

column2: Everything demonstrates it.
column3: Everything demonstrates it.

column2: Rubbing shoulders with men of all kinds----"
column3: Rubbing shoulders with men of all kinds----"

column2: You will forgive me, said the monk, meekly from under loads of white beard, "but I fear I do not understand; was it in order that I might rub my shoulder against men of all kinds that you put me inside this thing?"
column3: You will forgive me, said the monk, meekly from under loads of white beard, "but I fear I do not understand; was it in order that I might rub my shoulder against men of all kinds that you put me inside this thing?"

column2: An entertaining retort, in the narrow and deductive manner of the Middle Ages, replied the Professor, calmly, "but even upon your own basis I will illustrate my point.
column3: An entertaining retort, in the narrow and deductive manner of the Middle Ages, replied the Professor, calmly, "but even upon your own basis I will illustrate my point.

column2: We are up in the sky.
column3: We are up in the sky.

column2: In your religion and all the religions, as far as I know (and I know everything), the sky is made the symbol of everything that is sacred and merciful.
column3: In your religion and all the religions, as far as I know (and I know everything), the sky is made the symbol of everything that is sacred and merciful.

column2: Well, now you are in the sky, you know better.
column3: Well, now you are in the sky, you know better.

column2: Phrase it how you like, twist it how you like, you know that you know better.
column3: Phrase it how you like, twist it how you like, you know that you know better.

column2: You know what are a man's real feelings about the heavens, when he finds himself alone in the heavens, surrounded by the heavens.
column3: You know what are a man's real feelings about the heavens, when he finds himself alone in the heavens, surrounded by the heavens.

column2: You know the truth, and the truth is this.
column3: You know the truth, and the truth is this.

column2: The heavens are evil, the sky is evil, the stars are evil.
column3: The heavens are evil, the sky is evil, the stars are evil.

column2: This mere space, this mere quantity, terrifies a man more than tigers or the terrible plague.
column3: This mere space, this mere quantity, terrifies a man more than tigers or the terrible plague.

column2: You know that since our science has spoken, the bottom has fallen out of the Universe.
column3: You know that since our science has spoken, the bottom has fallen out of the Universe.

column2: Now, heaven is the hopeless thing, more hopeless than any hell.
column3: Now, heaven is the hopeless thing, more hopeless than any hell.

column2: Now, if there be any comfort for all your miserable progeny of morbid apes, it must be in the earth, underneath you, under the roots of the grass, in the place where hell was of old. The fiery crypts, the lurid cellars of the underworld, to which you once condemned the wicked, are hideous enough, but at least they are more homely than the heaven in which we ride.
column3: Now, if there be any comfort for all your miserable progeny of morbid apes, it must be in the earth, underneath you, under the roots of the grass, in the place where hell was of old. The fiery crypts, the lurid cellars of the underworld, to which you once condemned the wicked, are hideous enough, but at least they are more homely than the heaven in which we ride.

column2: And the time will come when you will all hide in them, to escape the horror of the stars."
column3: And the time will come when you will all hide in them, to escape the horror of the stars."

column2: I hope you will excuse my interrupting you, said Michael, with a slight cough, "but I have always noticed----"
column3: I hope you will excuse my interrupting you, said Michael, with a slight cough, "but I have always noticed----"

column2: Go on, pray go on, said Professor Lucifer, radiantly, "I really like to draw out your simple ideas."
column3: Go on, pray go on, said Professor Lucifer, radiantly, "I really like to draw out your simple ideas."

column2: Well, the fact is, said the other, "that much as I admire your rhetoric and the rhetoric of your school, from a purely verbal point of view, such little study of you and your school in human history as I have been enabled to make has led me to--er--rather singular conclusion, which I find great difficulty in expressing, especially in a foreign language."
column3: Well, the fact is, said the other, "that much as I admire your rhetoric and the rhetoric of your school, from a purely verbal point of view, such little study of you and your school in human history as I have been enabled to make has led me to-er-rather singular conclusion, which I find great difficulty in expressing, especially in a foreign language."

column2: Come, come, said the Professor, encouragingly, "I'll help you out.
column3: Come, come, said the Professor, encouragingly, "I'll help you out.

column2: How did my view strike you?"
column3: How did my view strike you?"

column2: Well, the truth is, I know I don't express it properly, but somehow it seemed to me that you always convey ideas of that kind with most eloquence, when--er--when----
column3: Well, the truth is, I know I don't express it properly, but somehow it seemed to me that you always convey ideas of that kind with most eloquence, when-er-when----

column2: Oh! get on, cried Lucifer, boisterously.
column3: Oh! get on, cried Lucifer, boisterously.

column2: I thought you wouldn't mind my mentioning it, but it's running into something now."
column3: I thought you wouldn't mind my mentioning it, but it's running into something now."

column2: Lucifer exploded with an oath and leapt erect, leaning hard upon the handle that acted as a helm to the vessel.
column3: Lucifer exploded with an oath and leapt erect, leaning hard upon the handle that acted as a helm to the vessel.

column2: For the last ten minutes they had been shooting downwards into great cracks and caverns of cloud.
column3: For the last ten minutes they had been shooting downwards into great cracks and caverns of cloud.

column2: Now, through a sort of purple haze, could be seen comparatively near to them what seemed to be the upper part of a huge, dark orb or sphere, islanded in a sea of cloud.
column3: Now, through a sort of purple haze, could be seen comparatively near to them what seemed to be the upper part of a huge, dark orb or sphere, islanded in a sea of cloud.

column2: The Professor's eyes were blazing like a maniac's.
column3: The Professor's eyes were blazing like a maniac's.

column2: It is a new world, he cried, with a dreadful mirth.
column3: It is a new world, he cried, with a dreadful mirth.

column2: It is a new planet and it shall bear my name.	It is a new planet and it shall bear my name.

column2: This star and not that other vulgar one shall be 'Lucifer, sun of the morning.' Here we will have no chartered lunacies, here we will have no gods.
column3: This star and not that other vulgar one shall be 'Lucifer, sun of the morning.' Here we will have no chartered lunacies, here we will have no gods.

column2: Here man shall be as innocent as the daisies, as innocent and as cruel--here the intellect----"
column3: Here man shall be as innocent as the daisies, as innocent and as cruel-here the intellect----"

column2: There seems, said Michael, timidly, "to be something sticking up in the middle of it."
column3: There seems, said Michael, timidly, "to be something sticking up in the middle of it."

column2: So there is, said the Professor, leaning over the side of the ship, his spectacles shining with intellectual excitement.

column2: Then a shriek indescribable broke out of him of a sudden, and he flung up his arms like a lost spirit.
column3: Then a shriek indescribable broke out of him of a sudden, and he flung up his arms like a lost spirit.

column2: The monk took the helm in a tired way; he did not seem much astonished for he came from an ignorant part of the world in which it is not uncommon for lost spirits to shriek when they see the curious shape which the Professor had just seen on the top of the mysterious ball, but he took the helm only just in time, and by driving it hard to the left he prevented the flying ship from smashing into St. Paul's Cathedral.
column3: The monk took the helm in a tired way; he did not seem much astonished for he came from an ignorant part of the world in which it is not uncommon for lost spirits to shriek when they see the curious shape which the Professor had just seen on the top of the mysterious ball, but he took the helm only just in time, and by driving it hard to the left he prevented the flying ship from smashing into saint Paul's Cathedral.

column2: A plain of sad-coloured cloud lay along the level of the top of the Cathedral dome, so that the ball and the cross looked like a buoy riding on a leaden sea.
column3: A plain of sad coloured cloud lay along the level of the top of the Cathedral dome, so that the ball and the cross looked like a buoy riding on a leaden sea.

column2: As the flying ship swept towards it, this plain of cloud looked as dry and definite and rocky as any grey desert.
column3: As the flying ship swept towards it, this plain of cloud looked as dry and definite and rocky as any grey desert.

column2: Hence it gave to the mind and body a sharp and unearthly sensation when the ship cut and sank into the cloud as into any common mist, a thing without resistance.
column3: Hence it gave to the mind and body a sharp and unearthly sensation when the ship cut and sank into the cloud as into any common mist, a thing without resistance.

column2: There was, as it were, a deadly shock in the fact that there was no shock.
column3: There was, as it were, a deadly shock in the fact that there was no shock.

column2: It was as if they had cloven into ancient cliffs like so much butter.
column3: It was as if they had cloven into ancient cliffs like so much butter.

column2: But sensations awaited them which were much stranger than those of sinking through the solid earth.
column3: But sensations awaited them which were much stranger than those of sinking through the solid earth.

column2: For a moment their eyes and nostrils were stopped with darkness and opaque cloud; then the darkness warmed into a kind of brown fog.
column3: For a moment their eyes and nostrils were stopped with darkness and opaque cloud; then the darkness warmed into a kind of brown fog.

column2: And far, far below them the brown fog fell until it warmed into fire.
column3: And far, far below them the brown fog fell until it warmed into fire.

column2: Through the dense London atmosphere they could see below them the flaming London lights; lights which lay beneath them in squares and oblongs of fire.
column3: Through the dense London atmosphere they could see below them the flaming London lights; lights which lay beneath them in squares and oblongs of fire.

column2: The fog and fire were mixed in a passionate vapour; you might say that the fog was drowning the flames; or you might say that the flames had set the fog on fire.
column3: The fog and fire were mixed in a passionate vapour; you might say that the fog was drowning the flames; or you might say that the flames had set the fog on fire.

column2: Beside the ship and beneath it (for it swung just under the ball), the immeasurable dome itself shot out and down into the dark like a combination of voiceless cataracts.
column3: Beside the ship and beneath it (for it swung just under the ball), the immeasurable dome itself shot out and down into the dark like a combination of voiceless cataracts.

column2: Or it was like some cyclopean sea-beast sitting above London and letting down its tentacles bewilderingly on every side, a monstrosity in that starless heaven.
column3: Or it was like some cyclopean sea beast sitting above London and letting down its tentacles bewilderingly on every side, a monstrosity in that starless heaven.

column2: For the clouds that belonged to London had closed over the heads of the voyagers sealing up the entrance of the upper air.
column3: For the clouds that belonged to London had closed over the heads of the voyagers sealing up the entrance of the upper air.

column2: They had broken through a roof and come into a temple of twilight.
column3: They had broken through a roof and come into a temple of twilight.

column3: They were so near to the ball that Lucifer leaned his hand against it, holding the vessel away, as men push a boat off from a bank.

column3: Professor Lucifer slapped his hand twice upon the surface of the great orb as if he were caressing some enormous animal.

column2: May I with all respect inquire, asked the old monk, "what on earth you are talking about?"
column3: May I with all respect inquire, asked the old monk, "what on earth you are talking about?"

column2: Why this, cried Lucifer, smiting the ball again, "here is the only symbol, my boy.

column2: Not like that scraggy individual, stretching his arms in stark weariness." And he pointed up to the cross, his face dark with a grin.

column2: I was telling you just now, Michael, that I can prove the best part of the rationalist case and the Christian humbug from any symbol you liked to give me, from any instance I came across. Here is an instance with a vengeance.	I was telling you just now, Michael, that I can prove the best part of the rationalist case and the Christian humbug from any symbol you liked to give me, from any instance I came across. column2: What could possibly express your philosophy and my philosophy better than the shape of that cross and the shape of this ball?
column3: What could possibly express your philosophy and my philosophy better than the shape of that cross and the shape of this ball?

column2: This globe is reasonable; that cross is unreasonable.
column3: This globe is reasonable; that cross is unreasonable.

column2: It is a four-legged animal, with one leg longer than the others.
column3: It is a four legged animal, with one leg longer than the others.

column2: The globe is inevitable.
column3: The globe is inevitable.

column2: The cross is arbitrary.
column3: The cross is arbitrary.

column2: Above all the globe is at unity with itself; the cross is primarily and above all things at enmity with itself.
column3: Above all the globe is at unity with itself; the cross is primarily and above all things at enmity with itself.

column2: The cross is the conflict of two hostile lines, of irreconcilable direction.
column3: The cross is the conflict of two hostile lines, of irreconcilable direction.

column2: That silent thing up there is essentially a collision, a crash, a struggle in stone.
column3: That silent thing up there is essentially a collision, a crash, a struggle in stone.

column2: Pah! that sacred symbol of yours has actually given its name to a description of desperation and muddle.
column3: Pah! that sacred symbol of yours has actually given its name to a description of desperation and muddle.

column2: When we speak of men at once ignorant of each other and frustrated by each other, we say they are at cross-purposes. Away with the thing!
column3: When we speak of men at once ignorant of each other and frustrated by each other, we say they are at cross purposes. Away with the thing!

column2: The very shape of it is a contradiction in terms."
column3: The very shape of it is a contradiction in terms."

column2: What you say is perfectly true, said Michael, with serenity.
column3: What you say is perfectly true, said Michael, with serenity.

column2: But we like contradictions in terms.	But we like contradictions in terms.

column2: Man is a contradiction in terms; he is a beast whose superiority to other beasts consists in having fallen.
column3: Man is a contradiction in terms; he is a beast whose superiority to other beasts consists in having fallen.

column2: That cross is, as you say, an eternal collision; so am I. That is a struggle in stone.
column3: That cross is, as you say, an eternal collision; so am i That is a struggle in stone.

column2: Every form of life is a struggle in flesh.
column3: Every form of life is a struggle in flesh.

column2: The shape of the cross is irrational, just as the shape of the human animal is irrational.
column3: The shape of the cross is irrational, just as the shape of the human animal is irrational.

column2: You say the cross is a quadruped with one limb longer than the rest.
column3: You say the cross is a quadruped with one limb longer than the rest.

column2: I say man is a quadruped who only uses two of his legs."
column3: I say man is a quadruped who only uses two of his legs."

column2: The Professor frowned thoughtfully for an instant, and said: "Of course everything is relative, and I would not deny that the element of struggle and self-contradiction, represented by that cross, has a necessary place at a certain evolutionary stage.
column3: The Professor frowned thoughtfully for an instant, and said: "Of course everything is relative, and I would not deny that the element of struggle and self contradiction, represented by that cross, has a necessary place at a certain evolutionary stage.

column3: After all it is easy enough to see what is really wrong with Wren's architectural arrangement."

column2: And the fruit should be at the top of the tree, not at the bottom of it."
column3: And the fruit should be at the top of the tree, not at the bottom of it."

column3: The new and childlike world which he had seen so suddenly, men had not seen at all.

column2: Here they were still at their old bewildering, pardonable, useless quarrels, with so much to be said on both sides, and so little that need be said at all.
column3: Here they were still at their old bewildering, pardonable, useless quarrels, with so much to be said on both sides, and so little that need be said at all.

column2: A fierce inspiration fell on him suddenly; he would strike them where they stood with the love of God.
column3: A fierce inspiration fell on him suddenly; he would strike them where they stood with the love of God.

column2: They should not move till they saw their own sweet and startling existence.
column3: They should not move till they saw their own sweet and startling existence.

column2: They should not go from that place till they went home embracing like brothers and shouting like men delivered.
column3: They should not go from that place till they went home embracing like brothers and shouting like men delivered.

column2: From the Cross from which he had fallen fell the shadow of its fantastic mercy; and the first three words he spoke in a voice like a silver trumpet, held men as still as stones.
column3: From the Cross from which he had fallen fell the shadow of its fantastic mercy; and the first three words he spoke in a voice like a silver trumpet, held men as still as stones.

column2: Perhaps if he had spoken there for an hour in his illumination he might have founded a religion on Ludgate Hill. But the heavy hand of his guide fell suddenly on his shoulder.
column3: Perhaps if he had spoken there for an hour in his illumination he might have founded a religion on Ludgate Hill. But the heavy hand of his guide fell suddenly on his shoulder.

column2: This poor fellow is dotty, he said good-humouredly to the crowd.
column3: This poor fellow is dotty, he said good humouredly to the crowd.

column2: I found him wandering in the Cathedral.	I found him wandering in the Cathedral.
column3: true

column2: Says he came in a flying ship.
column3: Says he came in a flying ship.

column2: Is there a constable to spare to take care of him?"
column3: Is there a constable to spare to take care of him?"

column2: There was a constable to spare.
column3: There was a constable to spare.

column2: Two other constables attended to the tall young man in grey; a fourth concerned himself with the owner of the shop, who showed some tendency to be turbulent.
column3: Two other constables attended to the tall young man in grey; a fourth concerned himself with the owner of the shop, who showed some tendency to be turbulent.

column2: They took the tall young man away to a magistrate, whither we shall follow him in an ensuing chapter.
column3: They took the tall young man away to a magistrate, whither we shall follow him in an ensuing chapter.

column2: And they took the happiest man in the world away to an asylum.
column3: And they took the happiest man in the world away to an asylum.
